subject: Re: [junit] Re: now it is almost working....
msgSnippet: If I were you I would either remove the package declaration from TestX or add one to test. if you add the the line: package mypackage; to X and the line import
messageBody:
If I were you I would either remove the package declaration from TestX or
add one to test.
if you add the the line:
package mypackage;

to X

and the line

import mypackage.X;
to TestX

The second solution is the preferred one since using the default package is
discoraged.
That shold fix the immediate problem. I can also warmly recomend going
through this tutorial http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/ and/or buy
Agile Java by Jeff Langr. It seems like a good place to start (though it
uses JUnit 3.8.1 you should have no problems adapting to JUnit 4.0 after a
few chapters).

We all have to start somewhere,
I hope this helps
/J



On 10/23/06, Magnus <t703093@...> wrote:

> assertEquals(666, new X().met(0));
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(-4));
